title: -educ vs school
summary: Drawing on a 2018 World Bank report, Don emphasizes the distinction between "going to school" and "gaining an education." He provides three evidence-based reasons: (1) Time in school is unreliable as a learning measure; better to set standards and allow time to meet them; (2) Education comprises multiple services—information, instruction, counseling, assessment, learning products, technology—most offered anywhere, while "going to school" is not itself an educational service (analogous to hospital or shopping plaza); (3) PEI's department title "Education and Lifelong Learning" seems redundant since education includes lifelong learning. Don notes that instructional services benefit from centralized locations, while non-instructional services (information, counseling) may serve better if decentralized. He proposes a lexicon of common educational terms, supporting his broader call for definitional clarity.
